com.idevicesinc.sweetblue.utils

Class Event

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.idevicesinc.sweetblue.utils.Event
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BleDevice.BondListener.BondEvent, BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent, BleDeviceConfig.BondFilter.CharacteristicEvent, BleManager.AssertListener.AssertEvent, BleManager.DiscoveryListener.DiscoveryEvent, BleManager.ResetListener.ResetEvent, BleManager.UhOhListener.UhOhEvent, BleManagerConfig.ScanFilter.ScanEvent, BleNode.ConnectionFailListener.ConnectionFailEvent, BleNode.HistoricalDataLoadListener.HistoricalDataLoadEvent, BleNode.HistoricalDataQueryListener.HistoricalDataQueryEvent, BleNodeConfig.HistoricalDataLogFilter.HistoricalDataLogEvent, BleNodeConfig.ReconnectFilter.ReconnectEvent, BleNodeConfig.TaskTimeoutRequestFilter.TaskTimeoutRequestEvent, BleServer.AdvertisingListener.AdvertisingEvent, BleServer.ExchangeListener.ExchangeEvent, BleServer.ServiceAddListener.ServiceAddEvent, BluetoothEnabler.BluetoothEnablerFilter.BluetoothEnablerEvent, BondRetryFilter.RetryEvent, DescriptorFilter.DescriptorEvent, NotificationListener.NotificationEvent, State.ChangeEvent

    public abstract class Event
extends java.lang.Object
    Abstract base class for all events in SweetBlue, e.g. State.ChangeEvent.

        public Event()

    • Method Detail

      • isFor

        public boolean isFor(java.lang.Object value)
        More reader-friendly of isForAll(Object...) or isForAny(Object...) in the event you only have one parameter to match.

      • isForAny

        public boolean isForAny(java.lang.Object... values)
        Convenience query method to check if this event "is for"/relevant-to any of the supplied values. For example for BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent you could write e.isForAny("DE:CA::FF:CO::FF::EE", "DE:AD:BE:EF:BA:BE") to quickly check if the event is associated with either of the two devices. This method would then just do a comparison with the input strings against BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.macAddress().

      • isForAll

        public boolean isForAll(java.lang.Object... values)
        Convenience query method to check if this event "is for"/relevant-to all of the supplied values. For example for BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent you could write e.isForAll("DE:CA::FF:CO::FF::EE", MY_UUID) to quickly check if the event is associated with both the given mac address and the given UUID (e.g. for a characteristic). This method would then just do a comparison with the input values against BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.macAddress(), BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.charUuid() BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.descUuid(), and BleDevice.ReadWriteListener.ReadWriteEvent.serviceUuid().
